posts.name: Ardiano Works
posts.cooked:
This is relatively new product I believe.

REV Robotics designs, builds and manufactures robotics parts and components used by students for learning about science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM). Our parts are commonly used within the FIRST Robotics Competition and the FIRST Tech...

Price: USD 300

Wondering how this performs, pro/cons, tradeoffs between others. Comparing the CADs, this module seems to have the most compact and least amount of # of parts compared to modules from SDS and WCP. This design is similar to Thrifty Swerve.

Thanks

posts.name: Brian Wagg
posts.cooked:
Defintely one of the newer modules out there. Released just back in November:

REV Robotics - 2022/23 Product Releases & Updates General Forum

3739 has been running them this season, and I’m thrilled with them. We’ve not run swerve before, but the example code provided helped us get up and running very quickly, and the modules themselves have been very robust thus far.

Their overall size is amazing too; Their size is just absolutely ridiculously tiny! We built our robot on a 24x24in chassis this year, and would have been hard pressed to have done that with modules any bigger than these.

Currently there is some concern with the default/stock wheels wearing too quickly, and in some cases the tread popping off the molded wheel:

MAXSwerve Wheel tread failures General Forum

We went through 2 sets of wheels at our week 1 event. We loaded in with the original wheels that shipped with the module kits, replaced those a few matches in due to worn tread (those wheels had been used all through build season for testing/driver practice too), then the new wheels failed in our last (maybe second last ) qualification match where we swapped out for another set of wheels going into elims.

REV is already working hard to ensure teams have enough wheels to compete, and have solutions for the wheel issues already in the pipeline:

MAXSwerve Wheel tread failures General Forum

The 1st module was a little tough to put together the first time, but once we figured out how to put the 1st one together properly, the others went together very smoothly.

Over-all I’d say we’re quite happy with our purchase/investment, and would recommend REV and their MAX Swerve to others looking to purchase some modules.

link_counts.title: Anyone used the new Rev Swerve Modules?

posts.name: Ardiano Works
posts.cooked:
Thanks for the info. One of the thing that I was concern about the module is if we needed to use 4" wheel which I believe pretty standard for other brands.

Did you do NEO or Falcon 500. Falcon has built in encoder on the back of the motor, this means we would not need the encoder that the module comes with with NEO.

Thanks

posts.name: Rohit Seshadri
posts.cooked: You would probably still want to use the absolute encoder with Falcons unless your team is fine with dealing with the hassle of rezeroing your modules before every match.

posts.name: Brian Wagg
posts.cooked:
The 3in worked fine for us this year. It really all comes down to ground clearance in my opinion. There’s around 2.75in of ground clearance which was plenty for this years game.

As for motors, we ran NEO’s on ours. We owned and ran falcons since 2020, but sold them this past fall due to the mass amounts of issues surrounding them.

The NEO’s have Integrated encoders in them just like the falcons. As @Rohit_Seshadri said, regardless of the Integrated encoders, you should still run the absolute encoders on the modules for accurate positioning/tracking of your module rotation across power cycles.

The MAXSwerve modules include the encoders anyhow (it’s not an additional cost like with a lot of other modules on the market), so there’s really no harm in running them. You’d also likely need to make some form of spacer to take-up the missing space that the encoder would typically occupy on the shaft.

posts.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
posts.cooked:
Performs great, other than the known wheel issue, which was easy enough to change.  We were pleased through Oklahoma regional.  Only team there with REV swerve this year, but later on several came to ask about it.  We wouldn’t have placed top 8 without it.

We used the high speed and mostly the stock template.  It looked fast compared to some others on the field.

We changed before, after first quals day, and only had a single bad wheel after last quals match, Anyhow having 3 sets of wheels per competition is probably good idea and changing before problems occur.

edit: I should add we weighed like 75 lbs which added to quickness.  Around 2 minute mark we end up leaving the substation with our quals partner and champion, at same time, and it was one time it just looked quick, like we were in a drag race of sorts. Qualification 59 - 2023 Oklahoma Regional - YouTube
posts.display_username: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)

posts.name: Ryan Swanson
posts.cooked: 6045 has been extremely happy with our MAX Swerve modules overall. No way we are as competitive without them!

posts.name: Ardiano Works
posts.cooked: Finally got my hands on the Swerve Modules. Man…It’s tiny.  I can’t wait to make this moves and put it thru its paces. It s our project this summer with my kids to get them to get hands on learning about Motor, Drivetrain, control, as well as programming. My plan is to build the flat chassis with 2 swerves diagonally and have 2 casters. Not sure how well this is going to work, so anyone who has experience on this please chime in. This is not a comp bot in any means, its more or less a learning experience bot.

posts.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
posts.cooked:
No experience with the casters, but give it a try and you can always go back if it is too hard to run that way.

I’m very happy to have the software from REV, both the set the absolute encoders and the code for running these modules.  But this summer I’d hope to dig deeper, either into some other template or just into some custom code to teach how the code handles the swerve states.

They are small, and it was a good project for the students assembling them, though you learned about how careful different people are.  Especially with adding loctite where needed.  But the assembly instructions were pretty well complete.

posts.name: SndMndBdy
posts.cooked:
billbo911:

Have any teams driven these with Falcon 500’s and the Neo 550 for steering?

We did and it worked very well.  You do need to switch the default spline shaft to one of the 3rd-party 8mm keyed shafts.

posts.name: billbo911
posts.cooked: Excellent,  I have 4 of the shafts on order as well. If all goes according to plan,  we will start off with Neo’s and plastic wheels.  Then, progress to aluminum wheels and Falcons. We may also work on a process to adapt Colson wheels.

posts.name: wgorgen
posts.cooked:
billbo911:

We may also work on a process to adapt Colson wheels.

We ran Colson wheels on our in-house custom swerve from 2017 through 2022. We switched to treaded wheels in 2023 (we also switched to SDS MK4i COTS modules). While the Colson wheels were great, the higher CoF from treaded wheels was definitely an improvement in terms of pushing power and the ability to resist being pushed around by defenders. Plus, it also helps acceleration as it raises the traction limited force that can be applied. I would also say that our experience this year with the stock SDS treads was that they wore as well as the Colson wheels, maybe even better. We were replacing our Colson wheels after just about every event in 2022 due to wearing through the tread (down to the hard plastic core), but we did not do nearly as many wheel changes with the SDS treaded wheels and were replacing them mostly as a pro-active step rather than as a result of wear.

We carry a full set of 4 spare wheels (8 wheels total) fully built up with the bearings and ring gear so that we can swap out the wheel quickly if needed. Since the treads can be replaced, we can take the worn set and put new treads on for the next replacement. The cost of the treads ($10 each) is less than the cost of the Colson wheels ($15 each), so the consumable costs are lower with the treaded wheels.

So, I don’t think there is really any advantage in trying to use Colson wheels.

posts.name: Ryan Dognaux
posts.cooked:
wgorgen:

So, I don’t think there is really any advantage in trying to use Colson wheels.

This is anecdotal but I know teams like 1501 and 3538 ran Colsons on their mk4i’s this season with little wear on their 4" x 1.5" Performa wheels.

It’d be interesting to hear how often teams swap tread though.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Having seen the FRC space go from favoring rough top to colson to rough top to potentially back to colson is wild.

link_counts.title: Product Release: Colson Wheel by SDS

posts.cooked:
Ryan_Dognaux:

It’d be interesting to hear how often teams swap tread though.

I think both of those teams felt that Colsons gave them an advantage getting onto the charge station. As for tread wear we didn’t replace our neoprene tread at all this season, i think part of that is we didn’t have a real aggressive driver this year.
